awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Stoma-Wafer Care Management Tool Using Mobile Phone Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a remote stoma monitoring and management technology to encourage telehealth for routine wound, ostomy, and continence (WOC) care consultations in order to reduce the burden on nurses, keep patients and the nurses safe from respiratory infections like COVID-19, and reduce the use of painful personal protective equipment (PPE) during routine checkups. This product may be adapted to wound care applications and used to monitor clinical wound healings with the use of 3D imaging. The product seeks to improve the precision of wafer fit and overall ease of stoma management while simplifying the appliance-fit process and empowering patients with easy-to-use tools to manage their stomas. The mobile technology could be used as a scanning device as well as a healthcare package to support individuals that have undergone an ostomy.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a software-based stoma-wafer inspection and fit tool that improves the precision of wafer fit and the overall ease of stoma management. In this system, a 3D model of the stomal area will be processed on a cloud-based backend, and an “ideal” aperture contour will be generated and used for automatic, high-precision wafer cutting. The product could be a reference for rethinking medical imaging technology that typically requires expensive image acquisition systems such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). While the initial focus of the product is to provide an affordable stoma care management system for patients, the technology could be applied to a wide range of other wound care products and fasteners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Prior to the National Science Foundation’s Innovation Corps program, our research direction aimed to explore the potential of smartphone technology in improving ostomy care, specifically through the customization of ostomy wafers. We hypothesized that precise wafer customization could significantly reduce health complications for ostomy patients, primarily elderly adults requiring frequent wafer changes.

Our project’s objectives for the I-Corps program were to 1) come to a clear go/no go decision, which in our case meant identifying a feasible and viable business model to assist ostomy patients in preparing their ostomy wafers – if such a model could not be found or iterated upon with our current technology, the decision would be to pivot or stop pursing this particular path; 2) substantial first-hand evidence for (or against) product-market fit, with a definition of the customer segments and corresponding value propositions; and 3) a narrative of a compelling technology demonstration for potential partners.

Engaging with over 150 stakeholders, including healthcare professionals and patients, was key in understanding the landscape of ostomy management and identifying unmet needs. Through these interviews, we discovered that various factors that would make our solution impractical. For example, the stoma size in the initial months post-surgery can change day by day, meaning our solution would require same-day shipping for customized wafers; however, the initial months is when patients would benefit the most from our assistance. Furthermore, discussions with nurses and patients revealed that we should expect less than 1% of patients would benefit from minimized complications with our solution, where the total number of new patients per year is a few hundred thousand in the U.S.

Our research efforts in this area have resulted in two published papers and two others in progress, demonstrating the potential of smartphone 3D scanning in achieving accurate measurements for ostomy care.

Moreover, the interviews highlighted a critical gap in wound assessment accuracy. Considering that our preliminary findings indicate an average measurement error of less than 10mm in ostomy outline extraction, with clear areas for improvements, we are confident in our new research direction, which aims to use smartphone 3D scanning to make objective and accurate wound measurement analysis available to healthcare providers of any skill level and in any discipline.

In collaboration with the VA Puget Sound Healthcare System, our current research focuses on improving 3D surface reconstruction techniques and processing wound models. This partnership not only validates our findings but also emphasizes the practical implications of our research in enhancing healthcare delivery.

The intellectual merit of our work lies in the innovative application of smartphone technology to a critical healthcare challenge, contributing to the body of knowledge in medical technology and offering a new perspective on patient care. The broader impact of our work is reflected in its potential to improve patient outcomes, streamline healthcare practices, and reduce costs, aligning with the NSF's objectives of advancing scientific knowledge and societal benefit.

Reflecting on our journey through the NSF I-Corps program, our project exemplifies the iterative nature of scientific inquiry, underscored by a commitment to addressing real-world problems through innovation. As we move forward, our work continues to be guided by the principles of rigorous research, stakeholder engagement, and the pursuit of solutions that offer tangible benefits to healthcare.


Last Modified: 03/14/2024
Modified by: Rania Hussein
